verses.text: Therefore hear the word of the LORD, you scoffers who rule this people in Jerusalem.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:14
rsbNotes.text: 28:14 scoffers . . . rule. These are foolish and wicked rulers (Prov. 1:22; 29:8).

verses.text: You boast, "We have entered into a covenant with death, with the grave we have made an agreement. When an overwhelming scourge sweeps by, it cannot touch us, for we have made a lie our refuge and falsehood our hiding place."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:15
rsbNotes.text:
28:15 covenant . . . agreement. They had chosen to ally themselves with Egypt for the purpose of remaining independent (30:2), but the choice was deadly.

lies . . . taken shelter. Their confidence was false (4:6 note).

verses.text: So this is what the Sovereign LORD says: "See, I lay a stone in Zion, a tested stone, a precious cornerstone for a sure foundation; the one who trusts will never be dismayed.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:16
rsbNotes.text:
28:16 Lord God. See note 25:7.

stone . . . sure foundation. See note 8:14–15. The sure foundation is Jesus Christ (cf. Ps. 118:22; Rom. 9:33; 10:11; 1 Cor. 3:11; Eph. 2:20; 1 Pet. 2:4–8).

verses.text: I will make justice the measuring line and righteousness the plumb line; hail will sweep away your refuge, the lie, and water will overflow your hiding place.
Your covenant with death will be annulled; your agreement with the grave will not stand. When the overwhelming scourge sweeps by, you will be beaten down by it.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:17
rsbNotes.text:
28:17 justice . . . righteousness. See note 1:21.

hail . . . waters. See note on v. 2.

refuge. See note 4:6.

verses.text: As often as it comes it will carry you away; morning after morning, by day and by night, it will sweep through." The understanding of this message will bring sheer terror.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:19
rsbNotes.text:
28:19 As often as. The Assyrian army marched through Israel many times.

terror. Divine judgment in human history brings people face-to-face with God’s power.

verses.text: The bed is too short to stretch out on, the blanket too narrow to wrap around you.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:20
rsbNotes.text: 28:20 short . . . narrow. The things people depend on for safety are neither adequate nor comfortable.

verses.text: The LORD will rise up as he did at Mount Perazim, he will rouse himself as in the Valley of Gibeon- to do his work, his strange work, and perform his task, his alien task.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:21
rsbNotes.text:
28:21 Perazim . . . Gibeon. In the past the Lord struck the Philistines (2 Sam. 5:19, 20) and the Canaanites (Josh. 10:10) at these places.

work . . . alien. The Lord will turn against His own people.

verses.text: Now stop your mocking, or your chains will become heavier; the Lord, the LORD Almighty, has told me of the destruction decreed against the whole land.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:22
rsbNotes.text:
28:22 scoff. They are responsible for any increased discipline.

decree. God ordains the events of history. See 10:22, 23.

verses.text: Listen and hear my voice; pay attention and hear what I say.
When a farmer plows for planting, does he plow continually? Does he keep on breaking up and harrowing the soil?

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:23–29
rsbNotes.text: 28:23–29 As timing is important for success in farming, so God has times for grace and for judgment.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:23
rsbNotes.text: 28:23 Give ear . . . hear. The prophet issues the call of divine wisdom (1:2; Prov. 1:8; 4:1; 5:1).

verses.text: When he has leveled the surface, does he not sow caraway and scatter cummin? Does he not plant wheat in its place, barley in its plot, and spelt in its field?
His God instructs him and teaches him the right way.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:25
rsbNotes.text: 28:25 emmer. Probably rye (Ex. 9:32). The comparison follows the natural order of plowing, breaking up the clods, harrowing, and sowing (vv. 24, 25).

verses.text: Caraway is not threshed with a sledge, nor is a cartwheel rolled over cummin; caraway is beaten out with a rod, and cummin with a stick.
Grain must be ground to make bread; so one does not go on threshing it forever. Though he drives the wheels of his threshing cart over it, his horses do not grind it.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:27
rsbNotes.text: 28:27 not . . . a threshing sledge. The different grains require different treatment; the Lord adjusts His judgment to circumstances and does not “plow continually” (v. 24).

verses.text: All this also comes from the LORD Almighty, wonderful in counsel and magnificent in wisdom.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 28:29
rsbNotes.text: 28:29 counsel . . . wisdom. See note 11:2. The scoffing rulers foolishly mock the one who is wonderful in counsel (cf. 9:6).

verses.text: Woe to you, Ariel, Ariel, the city where David settled! Add year to year and let your cycle of festivals go on.
Yet I will besiege Ariel; she will mourn and lament, she will be to me like an altar hearth.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:1–14
rsbNotes.text: 29:1–14 An oracle of woe against Jerusalem.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:1
rsbNotes.text:
29:1 Ah. See note 1:4.

David. Jerusalem’s claim to be the city of God springs from David (cf. Ps. 132).

year . . . feasts. This points out the repetitious and tiring observance of empty rituals. See note 1:11–15.

verses.text: I will encamp against you all around; I will encircle you with towers and set up my siege works against you.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:3
rsbNotes.text: 29:3 besiege. God refers to Assyria’s siege of Jerusalem in 701 b.c.

verses.text: Brought low, you will speak from the ground; your speech will mumble out of the dust. Your voice will come ghostlike from the earth; out of the dust your speech will whisper.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:4
rsbNotes.text: 29:4 low . . . whisper. These images describe Jerusalem’s experience of humiliation (2:10; 8:19).

verses.text: But your many enemies will become like fine dust, the ruthless hordes like blown chaff. Suddenly, in an instant,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:5
rsbNotes.text: 29:5 ruthless. See note on v. 20.

verses.text: the LORD Almighty will come with thunder and earthquake and great noise, with windstorm and tempest and flames of a devouring fire.
Then the hordes of all the nations that fight against Ariel, that attack her and her fortress and besiege her, will be as it is with a dream, with a vision in the night-

as when a hungry man dreams that he is eating, but he awakens, and his hunger remains; as when a thirsty man dreams that he is drinking, but he awakens faint, with his thirst unquenched. So will it be with the hordes of all the nations that fight against Mount Zion.
Be stunned and amazed, blind yourselves and be sightless; be drunk, but not from wine, stagger, but not from beer.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:6
rsbNotes.text: 29:6 thunder . . . fire. Nature rages when the Lord of the heavenly armies appears (6:4 note; Ex. 19:16–19; Judg. 5:4, 5; Ps. 18:7–15; Ezek. 32:6–8 note).

verses.text: The LORD has brought over you a deep sleep: He has sealed your eyes (the prophets); he has covered your heads (the seers).
For you this whole vision is nothing but words sealed in a scroll. And if you give the scroll to someone who can read, and say to him, "Read this, please," he will answer, "I can't; it is sealed."
Or if you give the scroll to someone who cannot read, and say, "Read this, please," he will answer, "I don't know how to read."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:10
rsbNotes.text: 29:10 seers. See note 30:10.

verses.text: The Lord says: "These people come near to me with their mouth and honor me with their lips, but their hearts are far from me. Their worship of me is made up only of rules taught by men.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:13
rsbNotes.text: 29:13 draw near . . . far from me. God desires expressions of devotion from the heart and hates empty ritual (1 Cor. 1:19; Col. 2:20–23).

verses.text: Therefore once more I will astound these people with wonder upon wonder; the wisdom of the wise will perish, the intelligence of the intelligent will vanish."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:14
rsbNotes.text: 29:14 wisdom . . . hidden. God will shatter human wisdom and planning (30:1–5; 31:1–3).

verses.text: Woe to those who go to great depths to hide their plans from the LORD, who do their work in darkness and think, "Who sees us? Who will know?"

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:15–16
rsbNotes.text: 29:15, 16 This oracle of woe against Jerusalem’s sages begins the third section of woes in chs. 28–33 (28:1–13 note).

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:15
rsbNotes.text: 29:15 counsel . . . deeds. They oppose the plans and works of God (11:2 note; Ps. 10:11; 64:5, 6). They try to manipulate God rather than submit to Him.

verses.text: You turn things upside down, as if the potter were thought to be like the clay! Shall what is formed say to him who formed it, "He did not make me"? Can the pot say of the potter, "He knows nothing"?

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:16
rsbNotes.text: 29:16 potter . . . clay. They overturned God’s order by their independent and haughty spirit (27:11 note; cf. Rom. 9:20).

verses.text: In a very short time, will not Lebanon be turned into a fertile field and the fertile field seem like a forest?

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:17
rsbNotes.text: 29:17 Lebanon. The forests of Lebanon will become fields, and fields will become forests. Judgment brings about such reversals; “the last will be first, and the first last” (Matt. 20:16; Luke 1:52, 53).

verses.text: In that day the deaf will hear the words of the scroll, and out of gloom and darkness the eyes of the blind will see.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:18
rsbNotes.text:
29:18 In that day. See note 2:11.

deaf . . . blind. These words are used here as figures for the people’s former spiritual conditions. The “deaf” are those formerly deaf to the message of God (42:18, 19; 43:8; cf. 6:10; 29:9). The “blind” formerly wandered from and did not discern the ways of God (42:7, 16; 56:10; 59:10; Lam. 4:14). The restoration of the spiritually “deaf” and “blind” is fulfilled today in Christ (61:1).

book. See notes on vv. 11, 12.

verses.text: Once more the humble will rejoice in the LORD; the needy will rejoice in the Holy One of Israel.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:19
rsbNotes.text:
29:19 meek . . . poor. See Ps. 9:18 note.

the Holy One of Israel. See note 1:4.

verses.text: The ruthless will vanish, the mockers will disappear, and all who have an eye for evil will be cut down-
those who with a word make a man out to be guilty, who ensnare the defender in court and with false testimony deprive the innocent of justice.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:20
rsbNotes.text:
29:20 ruthless. These people are the powerful and tyrannical oppressors of this world (13:11; 25:3–5; 29:5; 49:25; cf. Ps. 37:35; 86:14; Ezek. 28:7; 30:11; 32:12).

scoffer. This designation, common in wisdom literature, means a hardened and cynical person (28:14; Ps. 1:1; Prov. 1:22; 3:34; 9:7, 8; 21:24).

watch to do evil. Such a person is identified in v. 21.

verses.text: Therefore this is what the LORD, who redeemed Abraham, says to the house of Jacob: "No longer will Jacob be ashamed; no longer will their faces grow pale.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:22
rsbNotes.text:
29:22 redeemed Abraham. God accomplished redemption for Abraham by election and by covenant, promising him and his descendants the hope of the divine presence (cf. Josh. 24:14; Acts 7:2–4).

ashamed. Humiliated in defeat.

verses.text: When they see among them their children, the work of my hands, they will keep my name holy; they will acknowledge the holiness of the Holy One of Jacob, and will stand in awe of the God of Israel.
Those who are wayward in spirit will gain understanding; those who complain will accept instruction."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 29:23
rsbNotes.text: 29:23 children. Jacob’s hope lies in God’s gracious dealing with his offspring from generation to generation (49:20–22; 54:1, 13; 65:23).

verses.text: "Woe to the obstinate children," declares the LORD, "to those who carry out plans that are not mine, forming an alliance, but not by my Spirit, heaping sin upon sin;

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:1
rsbNotes.text:
30:1 Ah. See note 1:4.

stubborn children. These are Hezekiah’s counselors (cf. 1:2 note).

carry out a plan. The Hebrew could be translated “weaving a web” or “pouring out libations.” Either refers to making political alliances.

not of my Spirit. Human plans (v. 2) are opposed to the plans of the Spirit of God.

add sin to sin. Here we see stubbornness increasing (1:2–4) from the plan to act independently of God to the sin of injustice (v. 12; 10:1–4 notes).

verses.text: who go down to Egypt without consulting me; who look for help to Pharaoh's protection, to Egypt's shade for refuge.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:2
rsbNotes.text:
30:2 Egypt. In 701 b.c. Judah counted on Egyptian troops for help against Sennacherib (20:5, 6; 2 Kin. 8:21).

shadow. God alone provides His people with protection from danger (4:6; 16:3; 25:4, 5; 51:16; cf. Ps. 17:8; 36:7; 91:1; 121:5).

verses.text: But Pharaoh's protection will be to your shame, Egypt's shade will bring you disgrace.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:3
rsbNotes.text: 30:3 shame. From this experience of utter failure, the Lord promises to deliver those who trust in Him (54:4; 61:7).

verses.text: Though they have officials in Zoan and their envoys have arrived in Hanes,
everyone will be put to shame because of a people useless to them, who bring neither help nor advantage, but only shame and disgrace."

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:4
rsbNotes.text: 30:4 officials. Perhaps these were Judah’s ambassadors who went to Zoan (19:11 note) and to Hanes (fifty miles south of Cairo).

verses.text: An oracle concerning the animals of the Negev: Through a land of hardship and distress, of lions and lionesses, of adders and darting snakes, the envoys carry their riches on donkeys' backs, their treasures on the humps of camels, to that unprofitable nation,

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:6
rsbNotes.text: 30:6 oracle. See note 13:1.

verses.text: to Egypt, whose help is utterly useless. Therefore I call her Rahab the Do-Nothing.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:7
rsbNotes.text: 30:7 Rahab who sits still. The name Rahab alludes to a chaos monster defeated by the gods in Canaanite creation mythology (Ezek. 28:2 and note). The prophet mocks both the mythical monster and Egypt with a title meaning roughly “Rahab, who does nothing.”

verses.text: Go now, write it on a tablet for them, inscribe it on a scroll, that for the days to come it may be an everlasting witness.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:8
rsbNotes.text: 30:8 tablet . . . book. The oracles concerning the folly of dependence on Egypt were to be written down as a witness to future generations.

verses.text: These are rebellious people, deceitful children, children unwilling to listen to the LORD's instruction.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:9
rsbNotes.text:
30:9 children. See note 1:2.

instruction. The law that they are rejecting is the godly wisdom taught by Isaiah (cf. Prov. 2:1–5).

verses.text: They say to the seers, "See no more visions!" and to the prophets, "Give us no more visions of what is right! Tell us pleasant things, prophesy illusions.

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:10
rsbNotes.text: 30:10 seers . . . prophets. The preaching of many prophets conformed to the expectations of the people (9:15; 28:7; 29:10; 44:25; 1 Kin. 22:8; Jer. 6:14; 14:13–16; 20:9, 10; 28:8, 9; Ezek. 13; Hos. 9:7–9; Amos 2:12; 7:12, 16; Mic. 2:6–11; 3:5, 11). Others, like Isaiah, spoke by inspiration of the Spirit and under compulsion of a divine vision.

verses.text: Leave this way, get off this path, and stop confronting us with the Holy One of Israel!"

rsbNotes.title: Isa 30:11
rsbNotes.text: 30:11 the Holy One of Israel. See note 1:4.
